ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PETROL PUMP PRICES AND POWER SUPPLY


    1. Mrs Lim Hwee Hua asked the Minister for Trade and Industry what measures are in place to ensure that for sectors where there is little or no competition, such as local oil retailing and power supply, consumers' interests will not be compromised by the tardy downward adjustment or non-adjustment of prices.

    2. Dr Teo Ho Pin asked the Minister for Trade and Industry what measures can be

Column: 1261

taken to address the apparent oligopolistic behaviour of oil companies in Singapore.

    3. Mr Ong Kian Min asked the Minister for Trade and Industry, in view of the fact that crude oil prices in the international markets have fallen sharply in recent months, and that there is supposedly free competition among the oil majors in Singapore, why have local retail pump prices remained at such high levels.

    The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Mr Speaker, Sir, with your permission, I would like to answer Question Nos. 1, 2 and 3 together.

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: MTI's study shows that petrol pump prices have moved in tandem with crude oil prices in the past, but with a time lag. I would like to refer Members to charts (Cols. 1405-1408) 1 and 2 circulated earlier. Historically, the fluctuation of petrol pump prices is also not as sharp as crude oil prices, because crude oil is not the only cost component of running a petrol station. In fact, the proportion of crude oil price in the pump price is about 20%. Looking at the charts, we can expect pump prices to fall further if crude oil prices do not rise again.
Chart 1 - Crude Oil Price vs Petrol Premium (Cols 1405 - 1406)

Chart 2 - Crude Oil Price vs Petrol Intermediate (Cols 1407 - 1408)


    MTI has found no evidence of price fixing by the oil companies. Because the industry structure is oligopolistic, and the supply chain is long, price movement tends to be sticky and the companies prefer to compete on free gifts and loyalty benefits. Nevertheless, MTI is studying how we can introduce more competition into the petrol retail business. In the UK, 'white pumpers', which are petrol pumping facilities annexed to supermarkets and commercial buildings, have brought more players into the market. They have injected more competition into the UK market.

    MTI will work with the Ministry of National Development to study the feasibility of allowing such "white pump" sites,

Column: 1262

but without compromising on fire safety and environmental requirements.

    The power supply sector will be liberalised later this year. There will be additional electricity retailers besides Power Supply. These new retailers can compete for the larger consumers with customised competitive electricity products. Market forces will exert pressure on the retailers to innovate, provide better service and keep prices competitive.

    Dr Teo Ho Pin (Sembawang): Sir, may I ask the Minister whether the Ministry of Trade and Industry would consider taking other measures to stimulate competition among the oil companies in Singapore, such as introducing a competition law or supporting CASE's call for oil companies to display their petrol prices at pylon signages?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: MTI is studying the practicality of introducing a competition law for Singapore. It can introduce more competition but it can also cause rigidity in certain industry categories. So we are looking at the pluses and minuses of such a competition law for Singapore and weighing the pros and cons. For some of the FTAs that we are negotiating, having a competition law will be a subject for negotiation also.

    As to whether we should require petrol pumps to display prices on pylons, I believe this is something which is better for CASE to raise, because we should not require it by regulation that they must display their prices in a particular manner.

    Mrs Lim Hwee Hua (Marine Parade): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether there could be possible price collusion amongst the generating companies in future which may influence pool prices instead?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, I will soon be tabling legislation on the regulatory structure for increased competition in the power market. This will

Column: 1263

incorporate competition requirements and the power companies are not allowed to collude to fix prices. The regulatory agency will have the responsibility to ensure that price collusion is detected and not allowed.

    Assoc. Prof. Low Seow Chay (Chua Chu Kang): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether he is aware that a certain petrol company is offering as much as 10% discount on petrol price and, by offering 10% discount, it is still profitable, ie, there is still room for adjustment of petrol price. In other words, it seems to be overpriced.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, the fact that some companies offer discounts shows that there is a competitive dynamic at work and we should encourage more such competition by informing consumers that such discounts are available to them.

    Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam (Non-Constituency Member): The Minister speaks about introducing more competition. Does his Ministry accept that if the Ministry reduced this 3/4-tank rule that forbids Singaporeans getting cheaper petrol, there would be much more competition and there would be greater incentive for the petrol companies to bring down their prices?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, the 3/4-tank rule addresses a completely different problem. Any petrol retailer in Singapore is free to import crude oil or refined oil from any source outside Singapore. There is a 3/4-tank rule because we in Singapore tax petrol at different rates from those in Malaysia. In fact, until recently, there was a subsidy of petrol prices in Malaysia. If we allow motorcars to bring in full tanks from Malaysia, this, in fact, gives consumers a chance to evade the taxes which are imposed in Singapore and this would have a negative effect on our road usage policy.

    Mr Jeyaretnam: Is the Minister then saying that this 3/4-tank rule was introduced simply to get in more revenue for

Column: 1264

the Singapore Government at the expense of Singaporeans?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, the 3/4-tank rule was introduced to ensure the effectiveness of a policy designed as part of an overall programme to control the use of cars and roads in Singapore.

    Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar): Sir, would the Minister be reviewing the PUB charges and other related charges in the light of oil prices coming down?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, I will answer the question about PUB charges later on because there are other questions pertaining to this subject.

    Mr S. Iswaran (West Coast): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister, based on the charts, it does not seem so much that the petrol pump price lags behind movement in crude oil prices. It is just that it has been static and moves upwards when the prices go up. That appears to be the pattern anyway. So what would be the timeframe for any study that the Ministry undertakes to introduce greater competition in the industry structure at the retail level?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, if I may draw Members' attention to the charts, it is not true that it is a straight line going upwards. There are ups and downs.

    Mr Iswaran: It is not that it is a straight line going upwards, Mr Speaker, Sir, but more that it is a relatively less volatile line. If I look at the chart, it is quite evident that it has been quite flat, notwithstanding the movement upwards. And the greatest movement seems to be when price moves up at retail petrol pumps. The key question is: will there be a timeframe for this review to introduce greater competition at the retail level?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, our statisticians have looked at the charts and have not found, on the basis of the charts, the conclusion which Mr Iswaran has drawn, that the charts only move up and are sticky downwards. In fact, they reflect a certain evening out of

Column: 1265

the volatility. We are looking at the possibility of introducing more players into the market by studying whether we can introduce "white pumps" into Singapore without compromising on safety.

Column: 1265

ELECTRICITY TARIFFS
(Lowering)


    4. Mr Leong Horn Kee asked the Minister for Trade and Industry whether his Ministry will take immediate action to lower electricity tariffs for industrial, commercial and domestic consumers as international crude oil prices have fallen substantially in the recent months.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, in August last year, I explained in Parliament that our electricity tariffs are reviewed quarterly based on fuel oil price at the time of review. Changes in fuel oil prices are passed through to consumers. If oil price increases after the review, Power Supply would have under-collected. If, on the other hand, oil price decreases, Power Supply would then have over-collected. Power Supply is allowed to recover its under-collected revenue or, alternatively, is required to return over-collected revenue to consumers in subsequent quarters.

    The last tariff adjustment was made in August last year based on fuel oil price of US$24 per barrel. To reduce the impact of last August's tariff increase, Power Supply had agreed to recover its under-collected revenue over a longer period than the usual three months. For large non-domestic consumers, the collection was made over five months, ie, by end of last year. For residential and small non-domestic consumers, it was made over eight months, ie, the recovery of the under-collection would only be completed by March this year. If Power Supply had been allowed to recover its under-collected revenue over the usual 3-month period, the tariff increases in August last year would have been much higher and more severe.

    Fuel oil prices had subsequently increased to a high of US$28 per barrel

Column: 1266

in October 2000. Fuel price averaged US$25 per barrel in November 2000 before easing to US$21 per barrel in December 2000. As a result, Power Supply, which had kept the electricity tariffs unchanged since August 2000, has continued to under-collect. The revenue under-collected from residential and small non-domestic consumers is larger than that from large non-domestic consumers because the tariff increase in August 2000 was lower for residential and small non-domestic consumers. In other words, we had chosen to smoothen the volatility over a longer period.

    In November last year, Power Supply had applied to raise the electricity tariffs further based on the high fuel oil price in October 2000 which was US$28 per barrel. Power Supply subsequently revised the tariff adjustment with the easing fuel price. PUB has assessed and accepted the revised adjustment. With effect from February 2001, electricity tariffs for large non-domestic consumers will be reduced by 0.15 cents per kilowatt hour on average. However, in view of Power Supply's substantial under-collection from domestic and small non-domestic consumers, there is still a need for an upward adjustment of 1.41 cts/kwh for these consumers until April this year. If not for the easing of fuel oil price, this increase for them would have been even more. But if fuel oil price continues to fall, electricity tariffs will eventually fall.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to thank the Minister for the very detailed answer but I have a few queries. Firstly, will the present formula of having a quarterly review be reviewed because it seems like a long stretch to wait for three months to do an adjustment and, especially in the environment now where we are seeing a falling of oil prices, there should be a more frequent review?

    Sir, secondly, this formula that the Minister explained seems to be causing a lot of lumpiness in the calculation and computation of trying to recover the past losses. I want to ask whether this formula can also be reviewed and whether the

Column: 1267

Government actually imputes into it a profit element for the power companies because, if that is so, it means the Government is actually protecting these companies.

    My last question is, in view of this situation, will the Government introduce more competition in the industry, as he mentioned earlier, to allow for private electricity producers?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, Mr Leong has raised a very fundamental question of how we overcome the problem of price volatility. The stock market goes up and down, day by day, and we do not want the day-by-day volatility to be passed on directly to consumers. So we try to even them out. In the case of petrol pumps, the evening out is over such a long period that when prices do not respond immediately to price drop in crude prices, members of the public are upset. But we also recognise that if we pass all the volatility, you also create great disturbance in the market. If you look at the public transport companies, they have fuel equalisation funds. In theory, Power Supply can go into the futures market. But they can also guess wrong. There is no simple solution to this. And what we are working towards is letting the market settle the price structure. In other words, if you are a company which is very dependent on energy and you want stable electricity prices, you negotiate for that. You go into a long-term contract. If you are comfortable with month-by-month volatility, then that is what you get. We will be able to do this once the electricity market in Singapore is deregulated which we intend to do for big consumers later this year and for everybody in one or two years' time.

Column: 1267

SINGAPORE GENERAL HOSPITAL
(Hike in consultation fees for specialist-outpatient clinics)


    5. Dr Lily Neo asked the Minister for Health how does his Ministry (i) justify the

Column: 1268

big hike of 70% in the consultation fees for specialist-outpatient clinics (SOCs) at the Singapore General Hospital; and (ii) ensure the affordability of specialist care to the lower-income Singaporeans.

    6. Mr Tay Beng Chuan asked the Minister for Health (a) what is the justification for the Singapore General Hospital (SGH) to increase with effect from 1st December 2000 its consultation charges at specialist-outpatient clinics by as high as up to 70%; and (b) what productivity and control measures are put in place by his Ministry to prevent, in the future, spiral increases in operation costs and charges by SGH and other Government-linked hospitals with no regard to the affordability of the average Singaporean.

    The Minister for Health (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, can I be permitted to take Question Nos. 5 and 6 together?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Let me put the recent SGH specialist outpatient fee increases in perspective. The 70% increase in consultation fee applies only to private patients on repeat visits to the senior consultants, the most senior grade specialist in the hospital. In absolute terms, the increase is from $32 to $55. The rate of $32 before SGH's recent fee revision was close to the charges of GPs and therefore not reflective of the actual cost of specialist care rendered by a senior consultant. Therefore, the relatively larger increase is to better reflect the actual cost of specialist care as well as to close the fee differential for initial and repeat visits.

    The 70% increase in consultation fee does not apply across-the-board. For private patients on initial visits, the SOC consultation fees were raised by $13 to $18 and now range from $60 to $80, depending on the seniority of the doctor. This is an average increase of 30%. If we look at the total bill size, which includes prescription and other investigations which patients are more concerned with, the increase for private SOC patients is about 12%. As the last time SGH revised its SOC fees was in June 1997, the recent

Column: 1269

fee revision should therefore not be deemed excessive.

    While fees for healthcare services would have to be revised regularly, my Ministry will ensure that the cost of subsidised healthcare remains affordable. We will provide heavy subsidies to moderate fee increases so that healthcare continues to remain accessible and affordable to the middle and low income Singaporeans. In this recent fee increase by SGH, the consultation fees for subsidised patients, for both initial and repeat visits, were raised by $4 to $21. So for subsidised patients, whether they see the consultant for the first time or for repeat visits, they pay $21 for the consultation fee. This increase is reasonable given that the last time SGH revised its subsidised SOC consultation fees was way back in 1993. As for the total bill size for subsidised SOC patients, the increase was kept to about 8%.

    SGH's fee revision is unavoidable, given the economic recovery and the need for SGH to keep up with the increase in its operating cost, contributed largely by manpower, medical supplies and medical equipment. Nonetheless, our restructured hospitals will always be mindful of the need to moderate the increase in healthcare cost. As such, they have undertaken various productivity and cost saving measures, including bulk purchasing and e-procurement of supplies, implementation of electronic medical records system and skills redevelopment programmes to deliver more cost effective and efficient healthcare services to Singaporeans.

    For Singaporeans who still cannot afford to pay even the highly subsidised rates due to financial hardship, they can always apply for Medifund help. I would like to give the House my assurance that no Singaporeans will be denied essential medical care because of their inability to pay.

    Dr Lily Neo (Kreta Ayer-Tanglin): May I ask the Minister whether he has a breakdown on the cost of running specialist outpatient clinics, whether the increases of charges could have been

Column: 1270

spread out in stages and whether part of the cost could have been defrayed or absorbed by the hospitals.

    Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the fee structure of our SOCs is a little out of sync and therefore we have taken this opportunity to try and re-align it correctly. As I explained earlier, the SOC fee is structured accordingly to whether you see a senior consultant, consultant or a Registrar. So it is structured based on the seniority of the people you see. It is also structured on whether you see the consultant for the first time or for repeat visits. Based on this structure, we have a set of fees. For the private patients, the higher end of this structure will be when you see the senior consultant for the first time and that would now cost $80. If you see the Registrar for a repeat visit, which is the other end of the structure, it will cost you $35. So that is the range of fees. And to see a consultant, as a private patient, paying this range of fees from $80 or $35, I think, is a reasonable reflection of the actual cost of the consultant rendering the service.

    As a subsidised patient, we also follow this structure. But because of the very heavy Government subsidy, we charge a single rate of $21 to see a consultant and we do not vary, whether by senior consultant, consultant or Registrar, and we do not vary whether it is an initial visit or a repeat visit. So for subsidised patients, every time they go to the SOC, the consultation fee is a flat $21. But for private patients, we adopt this structure to better reflect the costs. For the subsidised patients, as I have explained, the fees have not been revised since 1993 and even in this revision, we have raised it by only $4. $4 over $17 is a big percentage increase, $1 over $17 is a 6% increase. So raising it by only $4, is already an increase of 24%. But $21, I think Members will agree with me, is a very affordable cost to pay to see a senior consultant in the restructured hospitals.

    Dr Lily Neo: May I ask the Minister whether the reason for the hike in specialist outpatient clinic charges is to address the cost of running such clinics

Column: 1271

or to address the long waiting times? If it is the latter, could other avenues, such as administrative policy and efficacy improvements be sought first before raising the charges?

    Sir, the more important amendment is the second component with regard to the Government's proposal on the treatment of the net investment income (NII). One principle that can be adopted is the treatment of the NII from a purely accounting approach. Under this approach, interests, dividends and other investment incomes earned from the past capital or equity of a company (ie, in the case of the Government's account and this will be the reserves) are treated as current account items, which means that such incomes including interests earned from past capital will be treated as items in the Working Capital, Cash Flows and Profit & Loss accounts of a company, and in this case of the Government's accounts.

    Under the same principle, a company that has borrowings from loans that were taken in the previous years, then the interest payable in the current year is also treated as a current account item, and netted off the yearly income. Sir, if this accounting principle were to be applied to the use of NII for Government accounts, then it is clear that NII which includes the interest from Government reserves should be added in total to the current year's income, and therefore 100% of the NII can be used by the new Government. On this basis, if the past Government has no reserves and has incurred debts for which interests are payable, then for the new Government, it could be faced with a negative or deficit income situation. The new Government would therefore have to bear 100% of this debt interest and fund the entire interest payable out of the present Government's current account of the year. On this purely accounting treatment basis, it can therefore be argued that 100% of the NII can be used by the present Government. However, we cannot conclude that the correct treatment of the NII from past reserves to be based purely on accounting principles. From the political point of view, it can also be argued that the entire NII earned from past reserves is income derived from the effort of past Governments and therefore any incomes earned from past reserves should form part of the past reserves.
